paragraphs.name: 50da
paragraphs.text: I’ve never understood why fans are okay with the whole concept of “the rules are the rules, except in big moments at the end of games.” If the rules say that play is a Flagrant 1 midway through the 1st half, then it’s still a Flagrant 1 with 11 seconds left in a one point game.

paragraphs.name: 60e3
paragraphs.text: The most boring first round of the tournament in years. The biggest upset was 12 over 5 (middle tennessee state) but that 12 was favored in Vegas anyway and everyone had them winning in their bracket.
The other ones, Wichita St, Xavier, Rhode island were all expected to win as well.

paragraphs.text: The benchwarmer “bullying” — oh my, seriously? They are happy guys who never get to see the court accomplish something. They are not mocking them.

paragraphs.name: d579
paragraphs.text: Archie Miller is a very good coach. If Indiana could get Marshall though, they would be reckless to pass on him.

content.subtitle: The Izzo comment made me laugh because it’s true.

paragraphs.name: 4b1d
paragraphs.text: Then again, this is the type of play that happens all the time at the ends of games and goes uncalled, so I’m not sure it’s fair to blame Rodriguez for not making a play on the ball either. Also, so much of what made the play look bad was Barford being inadvertently tripped by Rodriguez, leading many to wonder if the play would still have been considered a flagrant foul had Barford remained upright. I’m not sure what the right answer is. I just know that we were robbed of what may have been an all-time March Madness moment had the referees not assessed the play the way they did, and that truly sucks. I also know that, along with yesterday’s fouling mistake at the end of the Northwestern-Vanderbilt game, this means the two biggest moments of the 2017 NCAA tournament have been fouls. THE MADNESS IS ALMOST TOO MUCH TO HANDLE.
